dimensions.name: sleep_quality
dimensions.description: Inferred quality of sleep - the latent construct we want to improve. Manifested through sleep duration, wake timing, and next-day activity patterns.

dimensions.name: inferred_sleep_duration_hours
dimensions.description: Hours between last daily activity and first activity next day, serving as proxy for sleep duration
dimensions.how_to_measure: For each day D, identify the timestamp of the last entry. Then identify the timestamp of the first entry on day D+1. Compute the difference in hours. Record the value only if: (1) day D+1 data is available in the chunk, and (2) the gap is between 3.0 and 14.0 hours. Otherwise mark as missing. Units: hours (decimal, e.g., 7.5).
dimensions._changed: Clarified cross-day dependency handling, explicit missing value rules, and units

dimensions.name: browsing_cessation_time
dimensions.description: Time of day when last browsing activity occurred, as minutes since midnight. Values >1440 indicate past-midnight activity attributed to previous day's session.
dimensions.how_to_measure: For each calendar day, find the last entry. Extract hour and minute. If the entry is between 00:00-05:59 AND there was activity on the previous calendar day after 18:00, attribute this entry to the previous day's session and record as (24+hour)*60+minute (e.g., 02:30 = 1590). Otherwise record as hour*60+minute (e.g., 23:45 = 1425). Units: minutes since midnight (0-1799 range).
dimensions._changed: Renamed from browsing_cessation_hour; changed to minutes-since-midnight to handle wraparound; aggregation last→max; added explicit scale and attribution rules

dimensions.name: late_night_entry_count
dimensions.description: Number of browsing entries after 10pm, indicating late-night screen engagement
dimensions.how_to_measure: Count entries with timestamps between 22:00 and 23:59 on the calendar day, plus entries between 00:00 and 04:59 on the following calendar day (attributed to the late-night session). Each search, visit, or other entry counts as 1.
dimensions._changed: Renamed from late_night_browsing_minutes; dtype continuous→count; removed 'multiply by 2' computation; clarified what to count

dimensions.name: wake_time_minutes
dimensions.description: Time of first daily activity as minutes since midnight, serving as proxy for wake time
dimensions.how_to_measure: For each calendar day, find the first entry with timestamp at or after 05:00 (to exclude late-night activity from previous day). Extract hour and minute. Record as hour*60+minute (e.g., 07:13 = 433). If no entries exist after 05:00, mark as missing. Units: minutes since midnight (300-1439 range).
dimensions._changed: Renamed from wake_time_hour; changed to minutes for consistency; aggregation first→min; added 05:00 threshold to separate wake from late-night; specified units and range

dimensions.name: total_daily_activity_count
dimensions.description: Total number of browsing activities in a day, indicating overall screen engagement and usage intensity
dimensions.how_to_measure: Count all entries (searches, visits, views, other) for each calendar day. Each line in the data counts as 1 entry.

dimensions.name: technical_search_count
dimensions.description: Number of technical/programming searches indicating cognitive workload from knowledge work
dimensions.how_to_measure: Count entries where the search query or URL contains any of: haskell, python, linux, ubuntu, fedora, arch, algorithm, crypto, aes, rsa, tls, api, docker, git, database, sql, function, bug, error, stack, compiler, monad, functor, applicative, blockchain, puf, thinkpad, scalajs, ocaml, ruby, sentry, github.com, stackoverflow.com, hackage.haskell.org, arxiv.org, sci-hub. Case-insensitive matching. Each matching entry counts as 1.
dimensions._changed: Added case-insensitivity note; clarified URL vs query matching

dimensions.name: evening_technical_searches
dimensions.description: Technical searches after 8pm, indicating cognitively demanding work close to bedtime that may impair sleep onset
dimensions.how_to_measure: Count entries with timestamp at or after 20:00 where the search query or URL contains any of: haskell, python, linux, ubuntu, fedora, arch, algorithm, crypto, aes, rsa, tls, api, docker, git, database, sql, function, bug, error, stack, compiler, monad, functor, applicative, blockchain, puf, thinkpad, scalajs, ocaml, ruby, sentry, github.com, stackoverflow.com, hackage.haskell.org, arxiv.org, sci-hub. Case-insensitive. Each matching entry counts as 1.
dimensions._changed: Expanded term list explicitly instead of referencing other dimension

dimensions.name: is_weekend
dimensions.description: Whether the day is Saturday or Sunday, affecting schedule flexibility and social obligations
dimensions.how_to_measure: From the date, determine the day of week. Record 1 if Saturday or Sunday, 0 if Monday through Friday.
dimensions._changed: aggregation first→max for binary dtype consistency

dimensions.name: travel_period
dimensions.description: Whether travel-related activity occurred, indicating disrupted routine, jet lag potential, or vacation context
dimensions.how_to_measure: Record 1 if any entry contains travel-related terms: flight, airport, hotel, booking, airbnb, tripadvisor, roaming, visa, or location-specific foreign terms (sicily, siracusa, crete, heraklion, peru, lima, cusco, lavanderia, meteo + foreign city). Record 0 otherwise.

dimensions.name: health_search_count
dimensions.description: Number of health or medical-related searches, indicating health concerns or wellness interest
dimensions.how_to_measure: Count entries where query or URL contains: sleep, insomnia, apnea, medicine, drug, vitamin, supplement, symptom, disease, doctor, anxiety, depression, oura, fitbit, dreem, health tracker, antibiotic, vaccine, calorie, rdi, keto, celiac, tuberculosis, caffeine effect, side effect. Case-insensitive. Each matching entry counts as 1.
dimensions._changed: Removed substance terms (now separate dimension); added insomnia; clarified matching

dimensions.name: stress_level
dimensions.description: Latent daily stress level inferred from behavioral indicators like work intensity, health concerns, and browsing patterns

dimensions.name: mental_arousal_before_bed
dimensions.description: Latent mental activation level in evening hours, driven by stimulating content and screen exposure

dimensions.name: sleep_schedule_regularity
dimensions.description: Latent consistency of sleep/wake schedule over recent days, affecting circadian rhythm alignment

dimensions.name: caffeine_indicator
dimensions.description: Whether caffeine-related searches occurred, suggesting caffeine consumption that day
dimensions.how_to_measure: Record 1 if any entry contains: coffee, caffeine, espresso, cafe, starbucks, latte, cappuccino, nespresso. Record 0 otherwise. Case-insensitive.

dimensions.name: entertainment_evening_activity
dimensions.description: Evening leisure/entertainment browsing count, can be stimulating or relaxing depending on content
dimensions.how_to_measure: Count entries with timestamp at or after 18:00 where query or URL contains: youtube, netflix, spotify, music, song, movie, film, reddit.com (excluding programming subreddits), nightlife, restaurant, discoteca, wikipedia.org (non-technical articles), tripadvisor. Each matching entry counts as 1.

dimensions.name: substance_research_flag
dimensions.description: Whether psychoactive substance research occurred, indicating potential substance use affecting sleep
dimensions.how_to_measure: Record 1 if any entry contains: ketamine, piracetam, nootropic, microdosing, psychedelic, mdma, lsd, psilocybin, modafinil. Record 0 otherwise. Case-insensitive.

dimensions.name: very_late_night_activity
dimensions.description: Whether browsing occurred after midnight, indicating severely delayed sleep or insomnia
dimensions.how_to_measure: Record 1 if any entries exist with timestamps between 00:00 and 04:59 on the calendar day. Record 0 otherwise.

dimensions.name: search_entry_count
dimensions.description: Number of search queries (vs passive visits), indicating active information-seeking behavior
dimensions.how_to_measure: Count entries tagged as [search] or containing search engine query patterns (google.com/search, duckduckgo.com/?q=, bing.com/search). Each search counts as 1.
dimensions._changed: Replaced search_intensity (ratio computation) with raw count; model can relate to total_daily_activity_count

edges.description: Weekends allow later bedtimes without next-day work obligations
Weekends allow sleeping in without work schedule constraints
Weekends permit more late-night screen time without consequences
Travel planning and execution increases cognitive load and stress
Travel disrupts regular sleep schedule through time zones and changed routines
High technical workload increases cognitive stress and work pressure
Days with heavy technical work tend to spill over into evening hours
Complex problem-solving in evening keeps mind active and delays wind-down
More late-night activity mechanically delays the final cessation time
Screen exposure and engagement late at night elevates arousal through blue light and content
High mental arousal impairs sleep onset latency and reduces deep sleep
Later cessation reduces wind-down time and delays sleep onset
Later cessation directly compresses the available sleep window
Elevated stress impairs sleep onset through rumination and cortisol
Stress drives escapist browsing and difficulty disengaging from screens
Poor sleep quality leads to compensatory later wake times
Sleep quality affects sleep efficiency and time spent asleep
Poor sleep increases next-day stress reactivity and impairs coping
Poor sleep reduces next-day energy and cognitive engagement capacity
High overall engagement patterns carry into nighttime hours
Irregular schedules disrupt circadian rhythm and impair sleep quality
Variable bedtimes contribute to schedule irregularity over time
Variable wake times contribute to schedule irregularity over time
Caffeine consumption can impair sleep quality through adenosine blocking
Caffeine promotes alertness enabling more late-night activity
Health concerns and symptom checking increases anxiety and stress
Evening entertainment can be stimulating (exciting content) or calming depending on type
Engaging entertainment extends browsing sessions into late hours
Sleep duration affects next-day energy for engaging with screens
Substance use (if following research) can directly impair sleep architecture
Researching psychoactive substances may indicate self-medication attempts for underlying stress
Activity past midnight severely disrupts sleep timing and circadian alignment
Very late activity directly reduces sleep opportunity window
High search activity indicates active problem-solving mode, reflecting cognitive demand
Stress drives insomnia-like patterns and delayed sleep attempts
Weekends permit staying up past midnight without work consequences
